Often drawing on the pictorial codes of studio portraiture, staged tableaux and the family album, toaishara is conscious of the way performance can be revolutionary and how collective energy is built through care and embodied action. \n\n_a most beautiful experiment_ responds to Congolese photographer Jean Depara's documentation of Kinshasa's nightlife in the 1960s. Full of life and music, Depara's photographs animate a moment in history after the Democratic Republic of Congo gained independence from Belgium's brutal colonial occupation in 1960. toaishara's film is a non-narrative tapestry that foregrounds the role of dance as an agent of self-possession; the urban environment a stage for a transformative and intentional act of freedom-making. In its use of dance as a mode of poetic activism, this film sits in gentle dialogue with works in the adjacent exhibition.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 1998. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Tracey Moffatt Courtesy of the artist and Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery, Sydney.

Before he became a dancer, Nunukul and Yugambeh man Russell Page was a promising rugby league player. At the age of 16, overcoming an initial rebellion against the discipline of dance, he joined his brother Stephen at the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association (NAISDA) dance school in Sydney and emerged as a breathtakingly original and compelling performer. With their brother David, Stephen and Russell formed Bangarra Dance Theatre, with Stephen as artistic director, David as resident  
composer and Russell as the company's principal dancer.

In Tracey Moffatt's _Some lads_, Russell, along with fellow dancers Gary Lang, Matthew Doyle and Graham Blanco, animate Moffatt's makeshift studio at the Aboriginal and Islander Dance Theatre in Sydney. In front of a painter's drop sheet, they turn the space of the image into a zone of dynamic possibility. An important early work in Moffatt's oeuvre, the series is equally significant as a tribute to the vision and influence of an important community of First Nations performers who themselves effected a profound shift in the cultural landscape of Australia.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Purchased with funds provided by the Annual Appeal 2024

Â© Tracey Moffatt Courtesy of the artist and Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery, Sydney.

Graham Blanco (left), a descendant of the Mer (Murray Island) people, trained at NAISDA before establishing the Jaran Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander Dance Company in 2006. Here he is pictured with Russell Page.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Purchased with funds provided by the Annual Appeal 2024

Â© Tracey Moffatt Courtesy of the artist and Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery, Sydney.

Muruwari man Matthew Doyle was a founding member of the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre (AIDT) and subsequently worked with Bangarra as a Cultural Consultant and Songman on productions such as _Bennelong_ (2017). As a musician, he has performed at events such as the opening and closing ceremonies of the Sydney Olympic Games, at the opening of the Musee du Quai Branly, Paris, and of the Australian pavilion at the Venice Biennale in 2016. He is currently Cultural Advisor and 'Uncle in Residence' at NIDA.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Purchased with funds provided by the Annual Appeal 2024

Â© Tracey Moffatt Courtesy of the artist and Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery, Sydney.

Larrakia man Gary Lang (left), a dancer, teacher and choreographer, trained at NAISDA and joined Bangarra Dance Theatre in 1995. After five years with Bangarra he returned to Darwin and established the NT Dance Company, of which he remains Artistic Director. Graham Blanco is pictured at right.

gelatin silver photograph on paper

Purchased with funds provided by the Annual Appeal 2024

Â© Tracey Moffatt Courtesy of the artist and Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery, Sydney.

_Some lads_ can be considered the body of work by which Tracey Moffatt announced herself as one of Australia's most inventive and compelling visual storytellers. The photographs articulate what would become the distinctive characteristics of Moffatt's prolific practice: the coexistence of beauty, levity and wit with the incisive examination of race and its representation, deftly navigated through the overt use of artifice and performance. Unlike the staged ethnographic photographs taken of First Nations people by colonial photographers in the 19th century, the history of which Moffatt has routinely referenced in her work, the men in _Some lads_ are not passive or artificially posed. Rather they proudly and playfully engage with the camera. These are scenes of eruptive energy, where joy assumes a subversive power. This photograph features Graham Blanco.

pigment print on paper

Purchased with funds provided by Wayne Williams 2023

Â© Jacob Nash

Daly River artist and designer Jacob Nash was Head of Design at Bangarra Dance Theatre between 2010 and 2023, where he worked on over 20 productions. Alongside his design work, Nash produced photographs that document the action behind the scenes. While his photographs appear candid, they carry weight, capturing his subjects in the slip between the stage and the outside world. The dancers are photographed in the paint-up room, a sacred space where ochre is applied to the body in intentional designs. Through this process, the dancers become storytellers and are intimately connected to culture. Invited into this space, Nash captures this transformative practice with respect and reverence.  


This portrait of Beau Dean Riley Smith was taken backstage at Barangaroo, on Gadigal Land, while the dancer was waiting to go on stage for Bangarra's performance of _Spirit_ for the Sydney Festival 2021. Nash described the photograph as: 'A moment between two worlds. I have photographed Beau all over the country and world in moments where he is transforming from one spirit to another. I had never seen him in a hoodie pre-show before.'

type C photograph on paper

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the artist 2016

Â© Stuart Spence

Ningali Lawford-Wolf, a Wangkatjungka actor and dancer, began her career at the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theare, later performing with Bangarra Dance Theatre. Her award-winning 1994 one-woman show Ningali toured internationally in 1995, she performed in stage productions for various theatre companies and her film career included starring roles in _Rabbit-Proof Fence_ (2002), _Bran Nue Dae_ (2009) and _Last Cab to Darwin_ (2015). Off screen, she was involved in community work in Fitzroy Crossing, advocating on issues relating to education and employment and becoming a director of the Indigenous-owned Kimberley Agricultural and Pastoral Company. In 2019, Lawford-Wolf tragically died while on tour with the Sydney Theatre Company's adaptation of Kate Grenville's _The Secret River_, a production she helped create. A cultural consultant and artistic collaborator with Bangarra Dance Theatre, her legacy was honoured in their 2021 production _SandSong_.\n\nPhotographer Stuart Spence took this portrait of Lawford-Wolf for a series in which he asked his subjects to interpret the theme of water. Presented with a selection of props for the shoot, as Spence recalls, Lawford-Wolf 'instantly gravitated to the fish, draping it delicately around her neck'. Her gaze, confident and at ease, pierces through the image.

audio.title: Ningali Lawford-Wolf
audio.transcript:
(Ms Lawford-Wolf speaking in language)

I was sick and tired of white portrayal of Aboriginal people. And I wanted to write a theatre that was different, had all different forms of acting in it whether it be music, dance, singing, a monologue. And I wanted to stay in the traditional way of storytelling but make it real, make it different. And the only way, and the only way I can do stories like that was to fall back on myself and my plays, like â€˜You know, youâ€™ve got a story yourself, youâ€™ve been to Alaska when you were 16, you know, you lived here, you lived there, youâ€™ve come from Christmas Creek station, youâ€™ve come up from nowhere and make a name for yourself in the acting world and that is an achievement for someone my age. And I never really thought about it because I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m anything special. I donâ€™t know, Iâ€™m still quite naive in that aspect.

I wanted to make it honest too, â€˜cos you look at a lot of Aboriginal people that are working out there, thereâ€™s a lot of Aboriginal women that are working but not really strong Aboriginal womenâ€™s stories. And I wanted to make my point of view as a woman and as a proud Aboriginal woman, proud of where I come from, whether than be the backblocks of Woop Woop but yet that place still has a very big significance for me. I wanted to make Australia realise that they do have an Indigenous culture in Australia. They have it here. No, no, and Australia doesnâ€™t need to go anywhere else and adopt someone elseâ€™s Indigenous culture which a lot of people tend to do. But, you know, they have it here. And nobody hasnâ€™t discovered it, itâ€™s so funny going to Europe, for me, and more European people know more about Aboriginal Australia than Australians do so which is quite sad, which is really really quite sad. It goes to show how ignorant white Australia is.
audio.acknowledgements: Reproduced by permission of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation â€“ Library Sales. Awaye Â© 1996 ABC.

text.content:
inkjet print on paper

Purchased 2013

Â© Michael Riley/Copyright Agency, 2024

Wiradjuri/Kamilaroi artist Michael Riley's legacy within the Australian artistic landscape is profound. Riley was an integral part of the pivotal generation of First Nations artists working in photography and new media in the 1980s and, along with Tracey Moffatt and Brenda L Croft, one of the co-founders of the Boomalli Aboriginal Artists Cooperative in 1987. Riley's work is a form of careful veneration; his portraits of First Nations people possess a softness but also a profound strength.\n\nIn the 1980s Dolores Scott was a dancer with NAISDA. She went on to work as a publicist for Bangarra and later became an educator. Her mother, Dr Evelyn Scott AO, was an Indigenous rights activist and social justice campaigner, one of the leading campaigners in the 1967 referendum, and chair of the Aboriginal Council for Reconciliation.

inkjet print on paper

Purchased 2013

Â© Michael Riley/Copyright Agency, 2024

Wiradjuri/Kamilaroi artist Michael Riley's legacy within the Australian artistic landscape is profound. Riley was an integral part of the pivotal generation of First Nations artists working in photography and new media in the 1980s and, along with Tracey Moffatt and Brenda L Croft, one of the co-founders of the Boomalli Aboriginal Artists Cooperative in 1987. Riley's work is a form of careful veneration; his portraits of First Nations people possess a softness but also a profound strength.\n\nTelphia Joseph, a Wajarri Yamatji woman from Western Australia, is an academic specialising in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. In 1990, when she was photographed by Riley, she was a model and a dancer with the AIDT, which was a central part of the vibrant Aboriginal arts community in the inner west.
type C photograph\n\nÂ© Brenda L Croft/Copyright Agency, 2024

Across a four-decade career, artist, curator, lecturer and writer Brenda L Croft has probed the politics of representation, crafting a photographic output that disrupts the history of ethnographic documentation that has defined the way First Nations people were imaged since the 19th century. Deftly working between imaging techniques, from tintypes to photomontage, Croft returns agency and authority to her sitters, as is extant in this triptych portrait of Russell Page from the Nunukul (Noonuccal) people and the Munaldjali clan of the Yugambeh people of south-east Queensland. Page was a renowned choreographer, dancer, actor and, with his brothers, co-founder of Bangarra Dance Theatre. These photographs were taken when Croft and Page were in Venice for the 47th Venice Biennale, for which Croft had co-curated the Australian pavilion exhibition _fluent: Emily Kame Kngwarreye, Yvonne Koolmatrie and Judy Watson_. For the first two weeks of the Biennale, Page performed his interpretation of a painting in the exhibition, with artist Judy Watson painting the designs on his body. In each of these photographs, the agile Page appears to leap at the camera from within the embrace of a tree, bringing First Nations culture into the heart of the European art world.
type C photograph\n\nÂ© Brenda L Croft/Copyright Agency, 2024

labels.title: (Left frame - Egg) from 'Sticks and stones: egghead (William Dampier looking at himself)'
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross
labels.medium: oil crayon on mixed fur in antique frame

text.content: oil crayon on mixed fur in antique frame

William Dampier (1651-1715) was the first English person to explore parts of what is now known as Australia. In a 1697 account of his voyages to the South Seas, he described the Bardi people he encountered in the north-west of the country (later named Dampier Peninsula) in deeply derogatory ways. The racist language he used was profoundly consequential, and informed the views Captain James Cook and Joseph Banks took of Australiaâ€™s First Nations peoples 80 years later. \n\nIn this double portrait, Ross has depicted Dampier looking at himself. Her use of discarded animal pelts is unsettling; the soft fur is at once something we want to touch and something we turn away from in disgust. By renaming Dampier â€˜eggheadâ€™ and rendering his â€˜likenessâ€™ in rough black crayon, Ross pokes fun at this historical figure, and implores us to rethink his legacy.

engraving on paper\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Gina and Ted Gregg 2010

The establishment of the British colonies coincided with new types of publishing enterprise, including engraved portraits which were circulated widely in books and newspapers. In this display, Joan has surrounded a portrait of Wangal man Woollarawarre Bennelong (c. 1764-1813) with those of explorers, naval officers and colonial administrators such as Captain Matthew Flinders (1774-1814) and Governor Arthur Phillip (1738-1814). In 1789, Bennelong was captured on the orders of Phillip, who was under instruction to establish workable relations with local First Nations peoples. Bennelongâ€™s skills as advocate and interpreter saw him become a significant intermediary between First Nations peoples and the British. In this portrait Bennelong is encircled by symbols of his status as a warrior of the Wangal Eora, whose land flanked the southern side of the Parramatta River from present-day Darling Harbour to Homebush Bay.

audio.title: James Cook
audio.transcript:
Saw as we came in on both points of the bay, several of the natives and a few huts, men, women and children on the south shore abreast of the ship, to which place I went in the boats in hopes of speaking with them, accompanied by Mr Banks, Dr Solander, and Tupia.

As we approached the shore, they all made off except two men who seemed resolved to oppose our landing. As soon as I saw this, I ordered the boats to lay upon their oars in order to speak to them. But this was to little purpose for neither us nor Tupia could understand one word they said. When then through them some nails, beads, etc. ashore which they took up and seemed not ill-pleased in so much that I thought they beckoned us to come ashore. But in this we were mistaken, for as soon as we put the boat in again, they again came to oppose us, upon which I fired a musket between the two, which had no other effect that to make them retire back where bundles of their darts lay. And one of them took up a stone and threw at us, which caused my firing a second musket load with small shot. And although some of the shot struck the man, yet it had no other effect than to make him lay hold of a shield or target to defend himself.  
Immediately after this, we landed, which we had no sooner done than they throwed two darts at us. This obliged me to fire a third shot, soon after which they both made off, but not in such haste but what we might have taken one. But Mr Banks being of opinion that the darts were poisoned made me cautious how I advanced into the woods. We found here a few small huts made of the bark of trees, in one of which were four or five small children, with whom we left some strings of beads etc. A quantity of darts lay about the huts, these we took away with us.
audio.acknowledgements: Cook, James (1770) Journal of H.M.S. Endeavour, 1768-1771, 29 April 1770, OBJ 229040197 National Library of Australia

audio.title: Joseph Banks
audio.transcript:
May the first. The Captain, Doctor Solander, myself and some of the people, making in all 10 muskets, resolved to make an excursion into the country. We walked until we completely tired ourselves, seeing by the way only one Indian who ran from us as soon as he saw us.

The soil wherever we saw it consisted of either swamps or light sandy soil on which grew very few species of trees, one which was large, yielding a gum â€¦ but every place was covered with vast quantities of grass. We saw many Indian houses and places where they had slept upon the grass without the least shelter; in these we left beads, ribbons etc. We saw one quadruped about the size of a rabbit. My greyhound just got sight of him and instantly lamd [sic] himself against a stump which lay concealed in the long grass. We also saw the dung of a large animal that had fed on grass which much resembled that of a stag; also the footsteps of an animal clawed like a dog or wolf and as large as the latter.

May the second. The morn was rainy and we who had got already so many plants were well contented to find an excuse for staying on board to examine them. In the afternoon however, we returned to our old occupation of collecting, in which we had our usual good success. Tupia, who strayed from us in pursuit of parrots, of which he shot several, told us on his return that he had seen nine Indians who ran from him as soon as they perceived him.

May 3. Our collection of plants was now grown so immensely large that it was necessary that some extraordinary care should be taken of them. I carried all the drying paper, nearly 200 quires of which the larger part was full, ashore and spreading them upon a sail in the sun kept them in this manner exposed the whole day, often turning them. By this means they came on board at night in very good condition.
audio.acknowledgements: Banks, Joseph (1770) _The Endeavour Journal of Sir Joseph Banks, 15 August 1769 -12 July 1771_, State Library of New South Wales

audio.title: Arthur Phillip
audio.transcript:
Your Lordship has been informed that some of the convicts have been killed and wounded by natives, but that has I believe, never happened but when the convicts have been the aggressors. I have always found the natives friendly, and still retain the opinion I first formed of those people, that they do not betray a confidence placed in them.

In December 1788, one of the natives was seized for the purpose of learning the language and reconciling them to us, as mentioned in my former letter to your lordship, none of the natives having for some months come near the settlement. The man who was taken for that purpose appeared to be about 24 years of age and in three months was so reconciled that he was freed from all restraint and lived with me perfectly satisfied with his situation.

In the beginning of the following April, numbers of the natives were found dead with the smallpox in different parts of the harbour. It is not possible to determine the number of natives who were carried off by this fatal disorder; it must be great. And judging from the information of the native now living with us, and who had recovered from the disorder before he was taken, one half of those who inhabit this part of the country died. And as the natives always retired from where the disorder appeared and which some must have carried with them, it must have been spread to a considerable distance, as well as inland as along the coast. We have seen traces of it wherever we have been.

That they have some idea of a future state appears from their belief in spirits and from saying that the bones of the dead are in the chase, but the body in the clouds. And the question has been asked, do the white men go thither?
audio.acknowledgements: Phillip, Arthur (1790) _Official dispatch to Lord Sydney_, 13 February 1790, State Library of New South Wales

audio.title: Matthew Flinders
audio.transcript:
I yesterday enjoyed a delicious piece of misery in reading over thy dear letters, my beloved Ann. It is a general and benumbing course of misery that I undergo in this imprisonment, but by dwelling on thy most charming letters, every little of thy tender anxiety and distress, is afresh called up in vivid colouring to my maddened imagination. I am, as it were, shut up in a cask that has been rolled with violence from the top of hope down in the vale of misfortune; I am bruised and well-nigh stunned out of my senses; but cannot thou imagine the addition it would be to this misery for the cask to have been drawn full of spike nails; - such is the increase of misery to my feelings on thinking intensely of thee.

I have many friends, but yet before thee they disappear as stars before the rays of a morning sun. I cannot connect the idea of happiness with anything but thee. Without thee, the world would be a blank. I might indeed receive some gratification from distinction and applause of society; but where could be the faithful friend who would enjoy and share this with me â€“ into whose bosom my full heart could unburthen [sic] itself of excess of joy. Where would be that sweet intercourse of soul, that fine seasoning of happiness, without which a degree of insipidity attends all our enjoyments? From thee, my beloved, and thee only it is that I look to receive this zest for life, this height of luxury.

I love thee most tenderly. Heaven grant that neither ambition, or necessity may ever again divide us.
audio.acknowledgements: Flinders, Matthew (1804) Letter to his wife Ann from Mauritius, 24 August 1804. Retter, C. and Sinclair, S.,Â _Letters to Ann: The Love Story of Matthew Flinders and Ann Chappelle_, 1999, Pymble, Harper Collins

text.content: cast plaster\n\nPurchased 2000

A founding member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, Thomas Woolner produced medallions of prominent people, including naval officer and hydrographer Phillip Parker King (1791-1856). In 1817 King was appointed to explore the Australian coastline to consolidate the work of navigator Matthew Flinders, accompanied on the early voyages by experienced sailor and navigator Bungaree, of the Garigal clan. \n\nâ€˜Bungaree travelled with King and Flinders acting as a diplomat and was notoriously successful at negotiations with First Nations peoples. He was â€œgiftedâ€ the first Aboriginal land grant and the fake title â€œKing of the Broken Bay Aboriginesâ€. This shows the hypocritical nature of the colonistsâ€™ favourite propaganda tool, that these were unoccupied lands.â€™ Coby Edgar

high-vis safety material and crayon\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Rossâ€™ use of fluorescent yellow, a colour used to alert us to danger, is a visual response to the creep of hi-vis into the everyday environment. The uniform of construction workers or security forces, fluorescent yellow also readily signifies the presence of toxicity and is a visual shorthand for poison or radioactivity. Ross describes fluoro as a â€˜metaphor for colonisation, as a visual cue to show the invasion of something foreign and controllingâ€™. \n\nâ€˜You can do almost anything you want to the land if you wear a fluorescent vest and have the right piece of paper. Just like red jackets and the Union Jack, fluorescent uniforms are symbols of safety only to those whose lands and peoples are not in the firing line.â€™ Coby Edgar

text.content: hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

In quoting the work of colonial artists such as Eugene von GuÃ©rard, Ross retrieves these artifacts of Empire, unsettling the statements of possession and plenty they represent. In this work, beams of fluorescent light shoot across the vast landscape of Gundungurra and Dharug Country in the Blue Mountains, depicted in von GuÃ©rardâ€™s oil painting _Weatherboard Creek Falls_ 1863. In von GuÃ©rardâ€™s lithograph of the same scene, he replaced the First Nations figure in his original work with four European figures admiring the spectacular vista. Ross has repurposed the lithograph but returned First Nations people to the scene, where they are circled around a campfire. The title re-locates the setting from NSW to Van Diemenâ€™s Land (lutruwita/Tasmania), a further disorientation.
hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

â€˜For the most part, Australia has ignored the words and warnings of First Nations peoples and our knowledges have long been questioned. There have already been countless irreversible damages. Mass extinctions of unique flora and fauna, climate catastrophes. Yet Australia persists in its pursuit to destroy our natural world through mining. It is downright dangerous for all inhabitants of this country and continues to cause immense damage to First Nations peoplesâ€™ culture.â€™ Coby Edgar

â€˜Iâ€™m interested in shifting the narrative, in re-imagining the past. I am particularly interested in imagining that this man who came to Tasmania and cut all the trees down in an act of total disregard and insensitivity for the original inhabitants, has later in life realised what an enormous mistake he has made, that he has built his empire on greed.â€™ Joan Ross

â€˜Joan started her masterâ€™s thesis with the poem _Municipal Gum_ by Oodgeroo Noonuccal, a Quandamooka woman from Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island). When Joan was finishing her degree she used to visit her father who lived near a national park on the NSW south coast. She would float in the ocean and look back at the green landmass, no houses in sight, thinking about the trees and what they have witnessed. Oodgerooâ€™s poem spoke to the destruction of nature due to colonial greed, and said everything Joan was feeling.â€™ Coby Edgar

audio.title: Kath Walker part two
audio.transcript:
In 1965 I think it was, we were invited to go in and talk to the then prime minister, Sir Robert Menzies. There was a deputation from all over Australia of Aboriginal spokesmen and women and we did go in. Sir Robert Menzies had told the public and the politicians, the people of the House, that he would not have a referendum in his lifetime as prime minister. Heâ€™d been badly beaten on the referendum before where he had appealed to the people to outlaw Communism and when the people said â€˜No outlawing of the Communist Partyâ€™, Sir Robert Menzies refused then to have anything to do with referendums in his lifetime as prime minister.

We lobbied the House of Parliament and itâ€™s to their discredit, really, that when we asked them to bring out the laws concerning the Aboriginal people that there was no laws, no books on the Aboriginal people in their archives or libraries, and they had to quickly have them printed, so that the politicians could read what it was, for and against the Aborigines. There was one, however, on the national â€“ the Canberra law book saying that if Aboriginals go into Canberra, any Justice of the Peace could declare them illegal immigrants into Canberra and they could be chased out of Canberra. This still applied to us, incidentally, at this period of time. And we always made a joke of it when we went to Canberra, you know, â€˜If you get into trouble, you know the law on the book. If a JP says Get Out, make sure you get your blanket,â€™ because the law still said that before sending them out of Canberra, they must first issue them with one government blanket. So we were determined weâ€™d get our government blanket if ever they threw us out.  
We told everyone this and we made it a laughingstock â€“ Canberra a laughingstock â€“ to such an extent that the first thing Sir Robert Menzies did was delete that off the Canberra constitution. So itâ€™s no longer there.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Kath Walker is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

audio.title: Kath Walker part one
audio.transcript:
I would say that the majority of the Australian people voted Yes in favour of the Aboriginal people merely to clear their guilty conscience. Itâ€™s easy to put a mark on a ballot paper, and I must say this definitely, that there was a small minority group of sincere Australian people but I would say 75 [per cent] of those who voted Yes did it to clear their guilty conscience.

Incidentally, itâ€™s interesting to understand why those terrible discriminative laws were put into the books. In the first place, our civic fathers, or the white manâ€™s civic fathers of long ago, during the â€˜soothing of the dying pillowâ€™ era, the politicians, or the statesmen of that time, were writing over to Queen Victoria saying, â€˜The Aborigine is dying out.â€™ And true, he was â€“ they were poisoning him with strychnine in the waterholes and they were shooting him, and they were doing all sorts of things. And the Aborigine dropped from 300,000 strong to 80,000 in a very short period of time. So it was quite natural for them to say the Aborigine was a dying race.

Now it was during this period of time that the Constitution was being fixed, and as they thought we were a dying race, to save themselves a lot of bother they said, â€˜Well we will not count the Aborigines and we do not have to make laws for the Aborigines, because theyâ€™re going to die out anywayâ€™. And this is the reason today why Aboriginals have not had any education, any decent housing, any facilities that the white Australian enjoys today. Itâ€™s because of that stupid business of thinking the Aboriginals were going to die out.

Mind you, the Aboriginals are a determined lot, and theyâ€™re quite ungrateful. They didnâ€™t die, they lived on and are still living on; in spite of the many attempts to commit genocide and assassinate us all, we are still here. I think weâ€™ll last the white man out, truly.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Kath Walker is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

audio.title: Ooodgeroo Noonuccal
audio.transcript:
This is a portrait of portrait of Quandamooka woman Oodgeroo Noonuccal, formerly known as Kath Walker, created by Clif Peir in 1965. Oodgerooo was an activist, poet, writer and educator.

The portrait is a framed oil painting on board, measuring 104 cm high and 83.7 cm wide with the frame having a depth of 5.1 cm.

Oodgeroo is a slim middle-aged woman, seated angled to the left against a dramatic and moody background. Behind her, dark greens merge into black. Highlights of emerald green flicker across the sky and a brighter lime green surrounds her head. Flecks of white suggest distant stars beyond this green-tinted atmosphere.  
Two sharp craggy hills in deep shadow appear in the lower third, to the left of the subject. In front of them a spindly leafless tree reaches its fine black branches into the sky. 

In the foreground, Oodgeroo sits in a straight-backed chair upholstered in soft turquoise cloth. Her face is framed by black curly hair cut just below her ears. Her skin is a deep rich brown. Soft light filters down from the upper left, creating a gentle sheen of lighter brown across her brow, cheeks, the tip of her nose and chin.

Her large dark eyes, framed by strong black brows, gaze out to her upper left. The play of light also emphasises her prominent cheek bones, straight nose and full closed lips.

Her neck is long and slim, with the muscles on either side of her jaw standing out, stretching down to her exposed clavicle.

Oodgeroo wears a simple round-necked white blouse underneath an elegant formal cerulean blue jacket with white edging on collar and sleeves, with a matching tailored straight skirt. The portrait ends just above her knees.  
Her hands lie on an open book in her lap, right hand over left. The pages, sepia flecked with white, are empty.

Her relaxed pose and distant gaze give a sense of thoughtful introspection.

Audio description written by Krysia Kitch and voiced by Amy Midddleby

text.content: hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

In this work, the clash of fluorescent yellow against the heaving red of patterned carpet suffocates the VIP lounge where the poker machine spins and clicks. European figures taken from the grand manner portraits of Thomas Gainsborough play the game of colonial greed. The casual pull of the lever belies the high stakes of dispossession on First Nations peoples and Country. This is the gamble of the colonial land grab.
hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

In _Mâ€™Lady Ikebana_, a figure from Thomas Gainsboroughâ€™s _The Honourable Mrs Graham_, now dressed in fluorescent yellow and sporting flamboyant ostrich plumes, engages in ikebana, the Japanese art of flower arrangement. Ross notes that she references this traditional practice to recast the imposed structuring of nature as â€˜an act of total disrespect and disregard, which is how I see the impact of colonialismâ€™. Ignorant of the lutruwita/Tasmanian First Nations people that inadvertently become part of her display, the colonial lady arranges the stems of eucalypts - stripped out from John Gloverâ€™s _Natives on the Ouse River, Van Diemenâ€™s Land_ 1838 - into vases. Here is a landscape tamed.

labels.title: I thought I loved you that much
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

â€˜Joseph Banks brought greed to these shores and it never left. Joan is interested in how this has manifested itself in present-day society; we see greed as the â€œnormalâ€ now. There are people who never wear the same clothes twice. There is an entire generation with so much wealth that the next few may never own a home. There have been continuous wars over resources the world over. Before this greed, First Nations peoples didnâ€™t have homelessness, people didnâ€™t go hungry - they were fed by their Country and community.â€™ Coby Edgar

labels.title: Portrait of Dr Johann Reinhold Forster and his son George Forster
labels.subtitle: Jean Francois Rigaud

text.content: oil on canvas\n\nPurchased with funds provided by the Liangis family, the Ian Potter Foundation and John Schaeffer AO 2009

German/Scottish naturalist and writer Johann Reinhold Forster (1729-1798) taught languages and natural history in England before producing _A Catalogue of British Insects_ (1770). This and other publications brought him to the attention of Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander, and he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1772. That year he was appointed as a naturalist on Cookâ€™s second voyage on the HMS _Resolution_, accompanied by his son, George. Johann is depicted with a sprig of _Forstera sedifolia_ tucked in his hatband, holding a bellbird; specimens of a wattlebird, a saddleback and a honeyeater lie lifeless on the ground.
hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

The headless bird is a key motif for Ross. In this work she has beheaded a collared sparrowhawk originally painted in watercolour by an artist who came to Australia on the First Fleet, known as the Port Jackson Painter. Ross sees birds as ancient beings whose song carries the histories of connection and custodianship practiced by First Nations peoples. Australia has one of the highest extinction rates in the world. As more and more species become extinct with the acceleration of climate change, the artist wonders what will happen when the birds no longer sing.

labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

In this work, beams of fluorescent light shoot across the vast landscape of Gundungurra and Dharug Country in the Blue Mountains, depicted in von GuÃ©rardâ€™s oil painting _Weatherboard Creek Falls_ 1863. In von GuÃ©rardâ€™s lithograph of the same scene, he replaced the First Nations figure in his original work with four European figures admiring the spectacular vista. Ross has repurposed the lithograph but returned First Nations people to the scene, where they are circled around a campfire. The title re-locates the setting from NSW to Van Diemenâ€™s Land (lutruwita/Tasmania), a further disorientation.
hand-painted digital print on paper\n\nPrivate collection

â€˜In this work, Joan lays bare the devastation of colonisation for First Nations peoples and Country. It is a heartbreaking image of two women out in their nawi (bark canoe) fishing, the fire on their nawi ready to cook the fish and take it back to feed their families. But there is a big ship in the distance pulling a net full of fish that falls out of the frame toward the title, THE BEGINNING OF GREED. People who know the story of Barangaroo the celebrated fisherwoman and other Cammeraygal women who belong to Sydney Harbour and its surrounding waters understand this image deeper than the bulging net. The centring of these women in Joanâ€™s work is subtle but their presence vibrates through history.â€™ Coby Edgar
hand-painted digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

â€˜Joan takes 18th-century images and creates lies by using figures from one painting, a sky from an etching and a landscape from another. In this work, there are three different Joseph Lycett landscapes; the First Nations people were sourced from still more. It is so seamlessly stitched together as a fake composition that it looks real. Joanâ€™s work is a lie made from lies - but itâ€™s closer to a truth that many First Nations people would recognise as real. There were way more First Nations people around when Lycett was working, they were just deleted from the scene. The biggest lie was the claiming of the coast.â€™ Coby Edgar
ink and mixed media on card\n\nCourtesy of the artist
ink and synthetic polymer paint on card\n\nCourtesy of the artist
synthetic polymer paint and ink on card\n\nCourtesy of the artist

â€˜_My own piece of paradise_ prophetically taps into the absurdity of possession, superiority and ownership. Have you ever found yourself jealous, bargaining with the cards you were dealt and comparing your life to someone elseâ€™s? This work forces us to confront our belief that Country, and what we put on it or in it, can be truly _owned_. We live on Country until we die, and then our bodies and all our earthly belongings eventually become part of the Earth too. Why do we pretend that isnâ€™t the end game? Everyone and everything becomes part of Country. It owns you.â€™ Coby Edgar
ink and mixed media on card\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Arriving in Kamay/Botany Bay in 1788 as a captain of the marines on the First Fleet, Watkin Tench (1758-1833) maintained extensive journals later published in London in 1793. He described First Nations peoples, practices and technologies in detail, as well as local flora and fauna. Of the spiders he wrote:  


â€˜Their webs are not only the strongest, but the finest, and most silky I ever felt. I have often thought their labour might be turned to advantage. It has, I believe, been proved that spiders, were it not for their quarrelsome disposition which irritates them to attack and destroy each other, might be employed more profitably than silk-worms.â€™

Tenchâ€™s quote is referenced in Rossâ€™ video work _Barbie bush_, on view in the corridor.
hand-painted 3D print\n\nCourtesy of the artist

labels.title: Phillip ... a man with a mission
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: carpet and found painting\n\nPrivate collection

â€˜The narratives of explorers, surveyors, settlers, colonists of the lands and seas of this continent have been written, taught and repeated as a national identity over the past 200-plus years. Joan flips the familiar on its head and asks, do you really know these people? Is that really what you think or is it what you were told to feel and uphold as a legacy you benefit from and donâ€™t even realise how or why?â€™ Coby Edgar
oil on canvas\n\nPurchased with funds provided by the Liangis family 2015

As a naval officer accompanying Cookâ€™s third voyage, William Bligh (1754-1817) honed the navigational skills that would become, along with volatility and authoritarianism, his best-known characteristics. In 1787, he was appointed to command HMS _Bounty_ on a voyage to Tahiti, a journey that infamously ended in mutiny. Appointed Governor of New South Wales through the recommendation of Joseph Banks, Blighâ€™s brief was to curb the trade in rum and the influence of powerful, wealthy colonists. His abrasive manner and rigid adherence to orders created conflict over land, town planning and convict labour. Such issues led to him being deposed in Australiaâ€™s first and only military coup, the â€˜Rum Rebellionâ€™.

audio.title: William Bligh
audio.transcript:
I am now unhappily to relate one of the most atrocious acts of piracy ever committed. Just before sunrise, Mr Christian and the master at arms and several officers came into my cabin while I was fast asleep, and seizing me, tied my hands with a cord and threatened instant death if I made the least noise. I called sufficiently loud to alarm the officers, who found themselves equally secured by sentinels at their doors. There were now three men at my cabin door and four inside. Mr Christian had a cutlass and the others were armed with muskets and bayonets.

I was carried on deck in my shirt, in torture with a severe bandage around my wrists, where I found no man to rescue me. I asked the reason for such a violent act, but I was threatened to be put to death if I said a word. The boatswain was ordered to hoist the small cutter out, with a threat if he did not do it instantly to take care of himself. But on a representation that this boat was very leaky, he was directed to hoist the launch out. Mr Hayward and Hallet, midshipmen, and Mr Samuels, clerk, were now ordered into the boat. I assumed my authority and demanded the cause of such an order, endeavouring to bring someone to a sense of his duty, but it was to no effect. â€˜Hold your tongue sir, or you are dead this instantâ€™, was constantly repeated to me.

I continued to endeavour to change the tide of affairs, when Christian changed the cutlass he had in his hand for a bayonet and holding me with a strong grip by the cord that tied my hands, he continued to threaten me with instant death if I did not be quiet. The villains around me had their pieces cocked and bayonets fixed and particular people were now called on to go into the boat and were hurried over the side. With those people, I concluded of course, that I was to be set adrift. I therefore in making another effort to bring about a change, expressed myself loudly in such a manner as to be saluted with â€˜blow his brains outâ€™.
audio.acknowledgements: Bligh, William (1789) Logbook of HMS â€œBountyâ€, 1788-1790, 28 April 1789, Dixson Library, State Library of NSW

labels.title: Portrait of Captain James Cook RN
labels.subtitle: John Webber

text.content: oil on canvas\n\nPurchased by the Commonwealth Government with the generous assistance of Robert Oatley AO and John Schaeffer AO 2000

Captain James Cook (1728-1779) sailed the _Endeavour_ up the east coast of this continent in 1770 during Englandâ€™s first of three voyages to the Pacific. Between 1768 and 1779, he mapped vast areas that had previously been only tentatively investigated by European explorers, and ultimately effected ongoing consequences for the First Nations peoples and cultures of the entire Pacific region. John Webber joined Cookâ€™s third voyage in July 1776, making around 200 drawings and watercolours of topographical, natural history and ethnographic subjects. This portrait was completed in London three years after Cookâ€™s death in Hawaii in February 1779. In the context of this exhibition, and alongside Rossâ€™ own depiction of Cook, the painting demonstrates how portraiture was used to promote and perpetuate the colonial project.

audio.title: James Cook
audio.transcript:
Saw as we came in on both points of the bay, several of the natives and a few huts, men, women and children on the south shore abreast of the ship, to which place I went in the boats in hopes of speaking with them, accompanied by Mr Banks, Dr Solander, and Tupia.

As we approached the shore, they all made off except two men who seemed resolved to oppose our landing. As soon as I saw this, I ordered the boats to lay upon their oars in order to speak to them. But this was to little purpose for neither us nor Tupia could understand one word they said. When then through them some nails, beads, etc. ashore which they took up and seemed not ill-pleased in so much that I thought they beckoned us to come ashore. But in this we were mistaken, for as soon as we put the boat in again, they again came to oppose us, upon which I fired a musket between the two, which had no other effect that to make them retire back where bundles of their darts lay. And one of them took up a stone and threw at us, which caused my firing a second musket load with small shot. And although some of the shot struck the man, yet it had no other effect than to make him lay hold of a shield or target to defend himself.  
Immediately after this, we landed, which we had no sooner done than they throwed two darts at us. This obliged me to fire a third shot, soon after which they both made off, but not in such haste but what we might have taken one. But Mr Banks being of opinion that the darts were poisoned made me cautious how I advanced into the woods. We found here a few small huts made of the bark of trees, in one of which were four or five small children, with whom we left some strings of beads etc. A quantity of darts lay about the huts, these we took away with us.
audio.acknowledgements: Cook, James (1770) Journal of H.M.S. Endeavour, 1768-1771, 29 April 1770, OBJ 229040197 National Library of Australia

audio.title: James Cook audio description
audio.transcript:
Captain James Cook RN, seventeen eighty two, John Webber

This painting, oil on canvas, of Captain James Cook, is presented in an ornate gilt frame, with the carved leaf pattern.

Cook is depicted from upper thigh to the crown of his head. He poses out of doors. Behind him moody rain clouds are descending, tumbling from the top right of the picture, angling down past his shoulders.

At his right hip, a hint of breaking waves, and adjacent to the left hip, a muddy brown rocky outcrop and foliage.

Cook's mousy medium length hair is swept clear of his high forehead, into a ribbon tied at his nape. At his ears, almost like flaps either side of his face, a portion of his hair is drawn up and out, perhaps of fashion of the time. As his body is angled, so is his face and his left ear remains out of view. He has dark eyes and brows, a pale complexion with high colour in his cheekbones and across his nose. His lips are drawn together, neither pursed nor smiling. His expression watchful, tired.

A white cravat completely encases his neck. His white shirt in the style of the time is bedecked in numerous yellow gold buttons that finish below his hips, and the material parts at his groin to reveal white pants.

Encasing his torso, a rich cobalt coat with thick gold embroidered detail at his neck, along the lapels and from forearm to wrist. His right elbow is cocked, right gloved hand holds the material of his coat away from his shirt.

Cook's standing at an angle to us, his left shoulder partly obscured behind him by the angle of his body. The bare fingers of his left hand protrude, index finger flexed and drooping slightly as though the tail end of a gesture.

His left hand is close to the hilt of a sword on his left hip. Thick woven cord making an arc from the rounded end of the handle, to another point hidden in the fabric of his shirt.

**Audio description written by Jody Holdback and Emma Bedford and voiced by Rory Walker**

labels.title: The day I discovered something in myself
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross
labels.medium: crayon on lino and found painting

text.content: crayon on lino and found painting\n\nPrivate collection

â€˜Cook has become a symbol for colonialism, theft and genocide but in truth people like his filthy rich friend Joseph Banks, who had the coin and the connections, have much more to answer for. Cook was more of a 19th-century chauffeur than a villain. He wouldnâ€™t have had a ship to sail if Banks wasnâ€™t so keen on his own professional pursuits. But, in the end, that doesnâ€™t make his image less powerful.â€™ Coby Edgar
hand-painted digital print on paper\n\nPrivate collection

â€˜This work continues my interrogation of colonial collecting and of Australian colonisation, recreating the Leverian Museum in London, a catacomb of curiosities including those from Captain Cookâ€™s voyagesâ€‹. I imagine history as an unfaithful lover, in his own bubble with his lies, seduction and manipulation, only seeing from his position. Recontextualising Thomas Gainsboroughâ€™s Mr Andrews (from his painting _Mr and Mrs Andrews_ c. 1750) as the arrogant â€˜butterfly murdererâ€™, I render him unconcerned for the damage his infinite collecting causes.â€™ Joan Rossâ€‹

I imagine history as an unfaithful lover, in his own bubble with his lies, seduction and manipulation, only seeing from his position. Recontextualising Thomas Gainsboroughâ€™s Mr Andrews (from his painting _Mr and Mrs Andrews_ c. 1750) as the arrogant â€˜butterfly murdererâ€™, I render him unconcerned for the damage his infinite collecting causes.â€™ Joan Rossâ€‹
painted polymer resin\n\nCourtesy of the artist

labels.title: I like to name everything after myself
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: hand-painted digital print on paper\n\nCollection of Bernard Ryan and Michael Rowe, Singapore, courtesy of N.Smith Gallery, Gadigal Country / Sydney

â€˜â€œI discovered thisâ€ is a ridiculous statement. Everything already had a name when the colonisers arrived on these shores. Itâ€™s a disease of superiority to think that if you are the first of your kind to lay eyes on something, it somehow belongs to you. This mindset was used to erase First Nations culture.â€™ Coby Edgar

labels.title: View of Manly. Land of the tame
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: hand-painted digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

In _View of Manly. Land of the tame_, Ross employs a deft â€˜cut and pasteâ€™ technique to digitally collage various topographies from Joseph Lycettâ€™s _Views in Australia or New South Wales and Van Diemenâ€™s Land_ published in 1825. This composite of untruths is furthered by Rossâ€™ repurposing of an 18th-century engraving of a kangaroo to recreate a stone statue, carved by convicts, that still stands atop Manlyâ€™s Kangaroo Hill. Enjoying the view alongside her collared companion, a woman stands in a verdant landscape partly taken from Lycettâ€™s _The Sugar Loaf Mountain, near New Castle, New South Wales_ 1824. These fictional scenes echo the compilation of â€˜viewsâ€™ that formed the basis of histories written and repeated by those in positions of power.
hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

labels.title: Possession for men, Van Diemens Land
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

â€˜In her works, Joan shows the ridiculousness of possessing things. Once you have something, what do you do with it? Buy more? Keep it behind glass? Create laws to pass it down? What does it mean to possess?â€™ Coby Edgar

labels.title: James Macarthur
labels.subtitle: Unknown artist
labels.medium: black and bronze ink with white bodycolour highlight

text.content: black and bronze ink with white bodycolour highlight on buff board\n\nPurchased 2019

James Macarthur (1798â€“1867), landowner and politician, was the fifth child of early colonial pastoralists John and Elizabeth Macarthur. Born at Parramatta, James was tutored at home until 1809, when he travelled to England with his father, whoâ€™d been ordered back to London to account for his part in the overthrow of Governor William Bligh in 1808. John Macarthurâ€™s exile lasted eight years, during which James completed his schooling. After returning home he became involved in the familyâ€™s various agricultural ventures, and with his brother William he gradually progressed into the role of business and estate manager as his fatherâ€™s health deteriorated. \n\nThe reverse of this silhouette is inscribed â€˜J Macarthur Esq. of Camdenâ€™ â€“ Camden Park, near Menangle, New South Wales, being the familyâ€™s flagship property. This indicates it was made between John Macarthurâ€™s death in 1834, when James and his surviving brothers inherited the bulk of their fatherâ€™s estate, and the early 1840s, when photography started making silhouette artists redundant. It may have been made during Jamesâ€™ visit to England from 1836 to 1838, when he became engaged and was married.
watercolour on ivory\n\nPurchased 2013

Fanny Jane Marlay (1819â€“1848) came to Sydney with her free-settler family around 1825. In 1838, she met John Lort Stokes (1812â€“1885), an explorer, naval officer and surveyor appointed to HMS Beagle, which was then engaged in a surveying voyage of the Australian coast. In the course of it, Stokes charted much of what is now the coast of the Northern Territory; gave Darwin its name (after his former shipmate, Charles Darwin); and surveyed the Gulf of Carpentaria, the Arafura Sea, the Torres Strait, the Western Australian coast, and Bass Strait. He and Fanny married in Sydney in January 1841. Later the same year, Stoke succeeded to the command of the Beagle. Their daughter was born in 1842. Fanny returned with Stokes to England in 1843 and died while en route to Sydney again in 1848. Back in England from 1851, Stokes was eventually promoted to admiral. He died at his home, Scotchwell, in Pembrokeshire, in June 1885, survived by his second wife, Louisa, whom heâ€™d married in 1856, and by his daughter from his marriage to Fanny.

audio.title: Audio description - Fanny Jane Marlay
audio.transcript:
A portrait of free-settler Fanny Jane Marlay by an unknown artist in 1841. Watercolour on ivory positioned in a mountboard cut into a stretched octagon shape and coloured a deep mustard yellow. Encased in a velvet-lined burgundy case with a clasp on the right side it measures 7.5 cm in height and 6.3 cm wide. 

Fanny Jane fills the frame. Her pearly white skin contrasts with the blue of her garment and the dark brown background which enhances the creaminess of her complexion. The brush marks of the artist are evident with hatching and stippling of colours being used to create gradations in colour. 

She wears a sapphire blue broad brim hat which creates a halo around her face. The hat is elaborately decorated in white feathers that spill over the hat, drooping down towards her face and left shoulder.

Her hair is styled in loose finger waves covering her forehead and ears and pulled back. Elegant gold earrings with peach-coloured stones dangle from beneath her hair. Her eyebrows are slightly arched over almond-shaped and heavy-lidded eyes which are the same blue as her hat. Her nose is strong and straight, her cheeks coloured with a peachy blush and her narrow lips curve up in a subtle smile. Her long neck is adorned with a thick coiled gold necklace decorated with a peach-coloured stone in the centre to match her earrings. 

She wears a blue dress that complements her hat with a broad neckline that is edged in delicate translucent lace. The lace stands up, reaching towards her face, shorter at the front and becoming taller at the back with a triangular trimmed edge. This triangular edging is mirrored in the blue fabric of her dress, where the neckline is also trimmed in a row of blue triangles. 

**Audio description written and voiced by Alana Sivell, 2021**

labels.title: Fake memories
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross
labels.medium: plastic with brass locket and vinyl

text.content: plastic with brass locket and vinyl\n\nCourtesy of the artist
watercolour on ivory\n\nGift of Leo Schofield AM 2002. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.
watercolour on ivory\n\nGift of Leo Schofield AM 2002. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Mortimer Lewis (1796â€“1879), surveyor and architect, and his wife Elizabeth (nÃ©e Clements, c. 1794-1865) arrived in Sydney in March 1830 with their first four children. London-born, Lewis had worked as a surveyor and draftsman for almost fifteen years before being appointed to a position in the office of the Surveyor-General of New South Wales, Thomas Mitchell. Lewis assisted Mitchell in surveying areas of the Great Dividing Range and, at Mitchellâ€™s instigation, was appointed New South Wales Government Architect in 1835. During his fifteen year tenure in this role, Lewis oversaw the implementation of an ambitious program of public works, designing churches, schools, police stations, courthouses and prisons, as well as residences. Examples of his buildings include the courthouses and gaols at Darlinghurst and Berrima; the Customs House at Circular Quay; the Tarban Creek Lunatic Asylum (now known as Gladesville Hospital); the Kingâ€™s School, Parramatta; and Richmond Villa, constructed beside the Domain as Lewisâ€™s private residence in 1849, but relocated to Millers Point in the 1970s. Lewis also supervised the construction of Sydneyâ€™s Government House, designed in London by Edward Blore and comlpeted in 1845. Lewis resigned as Government Architect in 1849 pending an official enquiry that was to find that he had misappropriated materials intended for the first Australian Museum. Of his and Elizabethâ€™s five children, three â€“ sons Oswald, Mortimer junior and Frederick â€“ became architects. Lewis went into private practice with Oswald for a time. He died in Sydney in March 1879.

During the 1830s, Mortimer Lewis acquired seventeen acres of coastal land in what is now the Sydney suburb of Bronte. Lewis commenced building a villa on the property â€“ Bronte House â€“ but managed to complete only the dining and drawing rooms before being forced to sell in 1843. The house was completed for the new owners, politician Robert Lowe and his wife, Georgiana, in 1845.

Opinions vary on whether these portraits of Mortimer and Elizabeth Lewis were painted in England before they left for Australia, or are the work of a colonial artist. They remained in the collection of the Lewis family until being purchased by Leo Schofield, then the occupant of Bronte House, in 1998. They hung in Bronte House until gifted by Schofield to the National Portrait Gallery in 2002.

labels.title: Possession our latest perfume from Van Diemens Land
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross

text.content: hand-printed digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

The _Possession_ series is a suite of works about a fictional perfume. Subverting the aesthetic language of advertising, Ross likens the unbridled wanting and desire of colonial consumerism to our own experience as contemporary global consumers. \n\nâ€˜Possession is a perfume of greed and it probably smells like death and money. Joan can see the direct connection between greed, ego and superiority and the colonial project that is still running like a well-oiled machine, and is not afraid to make the connection obvious.â€™ Coby Edgar
watercolour on ivory\n\nPurchased with funds provided by L Gordon Darling AC CMG and Marilyn Darling AC 2013

Harriet and Julia Swan were daughters of John Swan (1796â€“1858), a tradesman and merchant who came to Van Diemen's Land in the early 1820s. Around 1826, he established Swan's Stores, which became one of Hobart's best shops, trading in clothing, millinery, fabrics and also 'household furniture and upholstery of the best description'. Swan and his wife Mary Anne had fourteen children. Harriet (1826â€“1853) and Julia (1834â€“1853) were the fifth and eighth respectively of their nine daughters. Harriet married an army officer named Edmund Isdell in Hobart in December 1850. Her first child, a daughter, was born at the Swan family home, Beaulieu, in present-day North Hobart, in December the following year. In July 1853, Harriet gave birth to a son but died a fortnight later, presumably of complications arising from childbirth. Julia died of scarlet fever, aged nineteen, at Beaulieu on 6 August 1853, a week after the death of her sister.
watercolour on ivory\n\nPurchased with funds provided by L Gordon Darling AC CMG and Marilyn Darling AC 2013

text.content: watercolour on ivory in a gold pendant with a lock of hair and gold thread\n\nGift of the Windeyer family 2009. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Richard Windeyer (1806â€“1847), barrister and politician, came to New South Wales with his wife, Maria, and infant son, William Charles, in 1835. In Sydney, he established a successful practice and was considered â€˜a barrister of superior abilitiesâ€™ and eloquence. He also acquired land in the Hunter Valley and at his Tomago estate engaged in winegrowing along with the cultivation of crops including wheat and sugar cane. Elected to the first New South Wales Legislative Council in 1843, he advocated free trade and worked to open British markets to colonial wheat. He was also interested in education, social welfare and law reform and became a member of the Aborigines Protection Society after appearing in trials arising from the Myall Creek atrocity of 1838. An â€˜able, enlightened, honest and uncompromising public manâ€™, Richard Windeyer died from a combination of illness, overwork and financial worries at the age of forty-one.

labels.title: George and Jemima Billet with family
labels.subtitle: C.H.T. Costantini

text.content: watercolour on paper\n\nPurchased 2016

Transported to New South Wales, and later Van Diemenâ€™s Land, CHT Costantini often painted subjects from lutruwita/Tasmaniaâ€™s landed middling classes. By 1838 he was in Launceston, spruiking his availability for â€˜portraits in the most correct style, also, views, and sketches of gentlemanâ€™s farms, &câ€™. In detailed compositions, Costantini faithfully rendered costume and jewellery, toys and furnishings, executed with flattened perspective and tight brushwork. These were portraits of possession. Jemima Billet sits surrounded by husband George and seven of the 12 children she would have between 1836 and 1858. While a young boy awkwardly clutches a ginger cat, perched upon the hand of the girl in blue is an Eastern Rosella, commonly kept as pets during this period.

audio.title: Billet Family audio description
audio.transcript:
This portrait, of colonial landowners George and Jemima Billet with seven of their children was painted in watercolour by convict artist CHT Costantini in about 1852. Framed with an outer wide band of dark, dappled, and textured wood and an inner narrow band of yellow gold, the portrait itself is 28 centimetres high by 23 centimetres wide. 

The portrait-oriented image is organised in three horizontal sections. The upper third is empty space, without image, and the colour of parchment. The mid-section is occupied by the nine family members facing us directly and occupying the full width of the image. The parents are shown in the middle of the work with the youngest at their feet, three older children to the right and three smaller children on the left. They share a formal, still quality. The figures are naÃ¯ve and appear almost cut-out, their overlayed arrangement suggests a receding background that allows the image to fluctuate between flatness and three-dimensionality. The lower tier of the overall composition is a carpet upon which the family stand. It is coloured with soft shades of green and decorated with circular evenly spaced and loosely painted gold and green floral motifs. The figures and their held objects are meticulously crafted, in contrast to the freely painted quality of the carpet. 

Moving from our right to left, Jemima and her two eldest daughters wear long-sleeved formal dresses that are cinched at the waist and extend downwards and outwards in ruched hoop skirts, forming large bell shapes. The daughter on the right has smooth mid-brown hair which is centrally parted and rolled on the sides to cover her ears. Her hair frames her softly rendered features, arched eyebrows, large blue eyes and pursed lips. Her mid-blue dress has a v-shaped neckline, a white-ruffle fronted shirt underneath and a small circular brooch pinned at the neck. She holds a pink flower in her left hand and the bent elbow displays loose sleeves adorned with geometric triangular embroidery. Her right arm reaches forward to rest upon her sisterâ€™s left shoulder. 

The sisters wear similar hairstyles and dresses. This sister has the addition of ringlets falling behind her ears and a soft apricot pink dress nearly identical to the blue. Her brown eyes are larger, and her neck is adorned with a choker of small brown beads above a white lace collar. Her wide skirts partially obscure those of her sister and mother and the colour almost merges with the parchment background. The sleeves are decorated with alternating red and blue horizontal stripes near the cuff. The toes of dainty pointed shoes are barely visible below her skirts. She stands in front of her mother but reaches backwards to grasp the back of the chair upon which Jemima Billet is seated. 

Beneath her arm, the open smiling face of one of the younger children peeps through. Half the size of the adults, her childâ€™s face is similar in scale and shares the features of brown hair and rounded eyes. 

In the centre of the work, Jemima Billet is seated on a chair. She is distinguished from her daughters by symbols of matriarchal status; a black dress and lace headpiece. The headpiece ties in a bow at the left under her chin. At the centre of her chest hangs a small, round blue pendant framed by a lace shirt and long fine gold necklace. She holds a white lace handkerchief in her hands which rest in her lap. Her husband stands on her right. 

George Billett is a head taller than Jemima and their adult daughters. His hair sweeps back from his forehead and curls inwardly at his ears around pale blue eyes. His long sideburns frame his serious expression. Georgeâ€™s black cravat is tied in an uneven bow over a cream shirt. An ornately patterned brocade-like vest contrasts with the open longer jacket and matching trousers of his black suit. His arm bends to allow his right thumb to hook into the pocket of his vest. At his feet sits the youngest child, a baby in a white dress, with blue bows at the shoulders. The child's left arm is raised and holds a bunch of multi-coloured flowers. Some petals have scattered on the carpet. A small blue boot hangs from their right arm like a charm. A necklace adorns the babyâ€™s neck.

Below the crook of Georgeâ€™s bent right arm are the remaining three children. They have blonde hair and happy smiles and wear shorter frocks that mirror the bell-like design of the adult dresses. The child directly below Georgeâ€™s arm stands in the far background, dressed in blue. They have short curls and blue eyes. In their left hand they hold a small colourful bird. In the foreground stands a taller child with straight hair and clasped hands, her lace edged pantaloons show beneath the pale gold of her frock above little black slippers. By their left elbow stands a short haired sibling. This child wears a grey dress with black details, buttoned down the front and drawn in at the waist with a tasselled cord. They wear buttoned boots and striped socks and hold a small pink cat.

In the foreground, directly in front of the baby, is a toy horse. It stands with arched neck, and trotting pose atop a red wheeled platform. Facing to the left of the work, the red string attached to the front of the toy meanders loosely upon the soft green carpet.

**Audio description script written by Meredith Hughes and voiced by Krysia Kitch**

oil on canvas\n\nPurchased with funds provided by the Ian Potter Foundation 2008

Ellen Stirling (nÃ©e Mangles, 1807â€“1874) was known in her lifetime as the â€˜mother of Western Australiaâ€™. The daughter of James Mangles â€“ an East India Company director and Member of Parliament â€“ Ellen was thirteen when she snared the attention of naval officer James Stirling (1791â€“1865), a family acquaintance. Described as â€˜adventurous, not yet introduced to the simpering ways of high society, wellâ€“educated, amusing and attractiveâ€™, Ellen is held by family lore to have been appealing to Stirling for her energy and lack of affectation. They were married on her sixteenth birthday in September 1823 and their first child was born the following year. In 1827, Stirling was given command of a voyage commissioned with identifying a new site for a British garrison on the west Australian coast. On his return to London, he presented the Colonial Office with a case for the establishment of a settlement on the Swan River. He was appointed lieutenant-governor of the new colony and in early 1829 Ellen sailed with him to the place that became Perth. Ellenâ€™s unpretentious manner served her well in a colony that, for the early part of Stirlingâ€™s tenure, was a dishevelled assortment of tents and timber houses. Stirlingâ€™s surveyor-general, John Septimus Roe, considered her â€˜affable and unaffectedâ€™ and her friend Georgiana Molloy wrote of Ellen as â€˜exceedingly amiable and pleasingly naturalâ€™.\n\nEllen maintained a gentrified style of living and as the colonyâ€™s pre-eminent lady presided at race meetings, hunts and other â€˜entertainmentsâ€™. Her charm and youth are said to have reflected well on her husband, softening some of the criticism of his governorship. Ellen had seven children during her ten years in Western Australia and another three following her return to Britain. Sir Thomas Phillips (1770â€“1845) was one of Regency Londonâ€™s most prolific and fashionable portraitists. He first exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1792 and by 1796 was primarily occupied with portraiture. Among his subjects were botanist Sir Joseph Banks; explorer Sir John Franklin; poets William Blake and Lord Byron; and scientist Michael Faraday. Records held by the National Portrait Gallery in London show that Ellen Stirling sat for Phillips just before she left for Australia, at which time she was several months pregnant with her second child. Her portrait was displayed in the Mangles family home in Surrey and remained in the possession of Ellenâ€™s descendants until acquired by the National Portrait Gallery in 2008.

audio.title: Lady Ellen Stirling
audio.transcript:
The departure of the _Hero_ affords me an opportunity of sending the box of plants, Number One, which I received full of fruit trees in February. The second box I also hope to ship but Mr Drummond who offered to fill it has been so dilatory that it has not yet made its appearance.

If my letter has reached you, you will know that Number One has been filled by Captain Meares. They all appear healthy plants. I sincerely hope the contents of both the boxes may arrive safely in England and that they may meet with your approbation. I should wish you to mention which of the two cases arrive in the best order and also which of the two contains the most valuable collection. Captain Meares will be much gratified to hear that his exertions have been successful, as he has been very kind in obtaining flowering shrubs. You will also receive by the _Hero_ the specimens collected and arranged by Miss Vittoria Meares and I think they are so well done that they will be valuable to you or at least to some of your friends.

Any curious fruit trees would be an acceptable offering to Captain Meares in return for what he has done. But as he is not overburdened with riches and the large cases are rather expensive, you had better send his portion with mine or in case of our having left the colony, make some arrangement about the payment. He is very clever with everything connected with gardening. When you write to him do not allude to what I have said about expenses.

The box which Drummond undertook to fill has not yet arrived. It is not my fault if it is left behind for I have done all in my power to hurry the old man but he is rather obstinate and likes to have his own way. All the fruit trees that came out in the last box are dead but those that arrived in the _Shepherd_ are very flourishing. I am going to ride to Woodmanâ€™s Point in quest of shells. I walked there and back the other day, a distance of twelve miles without picking up one, but I hope I shall be more successful this morning.
audio.acknowledgements: Stirling, Ellen (1837) Letter to her cousin James Mangles from the Swan River settlement, 3 November 1837, State Library of Western Australia

text.content: oil on canvas\n\nPurchased 2008. The original frame for this work was donated to the National Portrait Gallery of Australia by the National Gallery of Victoria 2009.

Throughout her practice, Ross has responded to works from the rich archive of colonial portraiture. In her ink drawings she reimagines such personages in their elaborate patterned costumes and coiffed hair, often representing herself as the colonial woman. This portrait of Martha Kermode (1821-1853) was painted in lutruwita/Tasmaniaâ€™s Central Midlands by Henry Mundy in the year after her marriage to landholder and politician Robert Quayle Kermode. In the painting Martha is attired in a silk satin evening dress, with dark ringlets cascading down her neck. Her familyâ€™s stature probably afforded her an education at the prestigious Ellinthorp Hall, where Mundy was a teacher. Married while still in her teens and subsequently the mother to several children, Martha died of tuberculosis at the age of 31.

labels.title: You were my biggest regret: diary entry 1806
labels.subtitle: Joan Ross
labels.support: stretched PVC with printed perspex backing

text.content: oil and alkyd paint on stretched PVC with printed perspex backing\n\nCourtesy of the artist

â€˜In this work, Joan makes herself the subject. In the background is a vista of deforested hills from an 1806 painting of Castle Hill Government Farm in Sydney. Joan opens up the possibility of empathy in hindsight; she mourns the destruction of Country and points to European exploration and exploitation as the cause. The greed of colonisation has literally changed the landscape forever and as an Australian, she is part of it.â€™ Coby Edgar
oil on canvas laid on composition board\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 2003

Maurice Felton emigrated to Sydney in 1839, where, for a brief period, he became the foremost portraitist in New South Wales. This portrait of Sydney-born Mary Tindale (1815-1882) is part of a pair, with the other a painting of her husband John Tindale, who she married in Bathurst in 1830. The couple were wealthy landholders by the time Felton painted their portraits, a status conspicuously pointed to by Maryâ€™s fashionable ermine wrap and delicate gold jewellery. Finished with ornate gold frames, Feltonâ€™s portraits were desirable symbols of position and privilege for aspirational clients.

lithograph on paper\n\nPurchased 1999

â€˜This assemblage of works speaks to families and ideas of ownership and class in the south-east, particularly South Australia and New South Wales. Joan pulls our attention to the many ways relationships between colonists and First Nations peoples panned out. Naturalist and painter George French Angas, for example, depicted First Nations people from South Australia, and his surviving family still have a relationship with their descendants today. Itâ€™s an uncomfortable collection of works because it evidences the trials of finding common ground. Something we are struggling with more acutely as a nation now given the global dynamics making it impossible to un-see the ongoing differences in the lives of the colonised and those who were colonists.â€™ Coby Edgar

labels.title: Bungaree, late chief of the Broken Bay tribe, Sydney
labels.subtitle: William Fernyhough

text.content: lithograph on paper\n\nGift of Dr Robert Edwards AO 1999. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

These works by artist and draughtsman William Fernyhough are from a series of 12 silhouettes of First Nations people that were intended not as caricatures but as faithful likenesses. Bungaree (c. 1775-1830), appearing here alongside his wife Cora Gooseberry (c. 1777-1852), was a Dharug voyager, navigator and diplomat who accompanied Matthew Flinders on the first recorded circumnavigation of this continent. Artist George French Angas wrote that while visiting Sydney in 1845, Gooseberry guided him to First Nations rock engravings at North Head. 

â€˜We selected historical representations of First Nations people we thought were the most respectfully depicted in the collection; works that show some visibility of pride,  
of culture, of self-determination.â€™ Coby Edgar

labels.title: Punch, wife of Cullabaa, Broken Bay tribe
labels.subtitle: William Fernyhough

text.content: lithograph on paper\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Dr Robert Edwards AO 1999 Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program

These works by artist and draughtsman William Fernyhough are from a series of 12 silhouettes of First Nations people that were intended not as caricatures but as faithful likenesses. Bungaree (c. 1775-1830), appearing here alongside his wife Cora Gooseberry (c. 1777-1852), was a Dharug voyager, navigator and diplomat who accompanied Matthew Flinders on the first recorded circumnavigation of this continent. Artist George French Angas wrote that while visiting Sydney in 1845, Gooseberry guided him to First Nations rock engravings at North Head. 

â€˜We selected historical representations of First Nations people we thought were the most respectfully depicted in the collection; works that show some visibility of pride,  
of culture, of self-determination.â€™ Coby Edgar
